awd_titl_txt: Assessing Alterations to Planktonic Community Composition in a Changing Arctic Ocean
awd_abstract_narration:
The Arctic Ocean is undergoing rapid environmental change, yet potential impacts on its living organisms is poorly known. Sparse observations have suggested that a shift in the composition of Arctic Ocean phytoplankton species may already be occurring. These types of shifts in the planktonic community can echo throughout the Arctic food web, affecting higher-level consumers that serve as important commercial resources or sustenance for northern communities. The proposed work will develop new optically-based tools to be used in situ and through remote sensing to understand patterns in planktonic community composition now and in the future. Graduate and undergraduate student researchers supported by this project will receive practical training in environmental science through participation in laboratory and field research, data analysis and interpretation, and numerical analyses. The investigators will conduct public outreach in collaboration with educational venues such as the Birch Aquarium at Scripps.

The investigators will establish and analyze a multi-decadal baseline of observations that describes the spatial distributions of planktonic communities in the western Arctic Ocean with the goal of developing optical tools and approaches that can be broadly applied to understand future environmental change in the region. Activities include a combination of (i) field work in the Chukchi and Beaufort Seas through collaboration with a Japanese research program, (ii) the development of optically-based algorithms for discerning planktonic community assemblages, and (iii) application of these algorithms to satellite remote-sensing data. The field work will include observations of planktonic community structure and connect these to seawater optical properties in the study area at different seasonal time periods. In addition, the investigators will use phytoplankton pigment measurements to infer spatial patterns of planktonic community composition and address the hypothesis that optical measurements can identify distinct planktonic assemblages. Finally, the project will develop and validate algorithms relating seawater optical properties to planktonic community structure and apply these to a time series of ocean color imagery to generate spatial maps of plankton community composition within the surface ocean.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The pelagic habitat of the Arctic Ocean is undergoing rapid environmental change with unknown impacts on planktonic community structure that may alter ecosystem function and the oceanic food web. The goal of this project was to explore and develop approaches to discriminate planktonic assemblages from optical measurements that can be obtained from in situ or remote sensing instrumentation, enabling better monitoring of this environment and providing assessment of ongoing and future trends.

Utilizing a database of observations from four Arctic cruises assembled as part of this project, we conducted a comprehensive characterization of Arctic seawater optical properties and examined how these properties vary in relation to phytoplankton community size structure. We demonstrated measurable differences in the average spectral shapes of the phytoplankton absorption coefficient that are associated with the relative contributions of different-sized phytoplankton taxa to the suspended particle assemblage. Furthermore, we also documented systematic differences in the spectral shape of the remote-sensing reflectance (ocean color) among these communities. These observations suggest potential approaches to assess phytoplankton community composition from measurements of seawater optical properties, and are being used to formulate remote-sensing algorithms that will enable determination of how the spatial distributions of these communities vary over time in Arctic seas.

The particle size distribution (PSD) is also an important characteristic of suspended oceanic particles that influences ocean ecology and biogeochemistry, and describes how the concentration of particles changes with particle size. Using our database, we showed that a commonly-used model of the PSD employed in aquatic studies has strong limitations in representing the PSD of natural samples from Arctic waters. We developed a novel alternative method to describe the PSD based on the cumulative distribution of size-dependent particle concentration, and demonstrated that it provides a better means to characterize the shape of the PSD for suspended particle assemblages in Arctic seas. We further showed that this approach developed for the Arctic also provides superior performance when applied to data from other oceanic regions in the Pacific and Atlantic Oceans, and thus is generally applicable to a variety of diverse marine environments. As this approach is potentially amenable to use with optical measurements obtained from autonomous sensing platforms, these results could greatly enhance the observational capabilities of suspended particle size in the oceanic environment.

A major challenge to the use of optical remote sensing in the Arctic Ocean is the complex and variable composition of suspended particulate matter, which has a strong influence on the optical properties of seawater. To address this challenge, we developed a new modeling approach to estimate biogeochemical properties of Arctic seawater that accounts for this variability. An optically-derived parameter is first derived and used to classify water bodies based on the relative contributions of organic and inorganic particles to the suspended particle assemblage, and an appropriate algorithm is then applied based upon this classification. We demonstrated this adaptive approach to the estimation of particulate organic carbon concentrations from optical measurements along a continuum of Arctic environments, and showed that it provides significant improvements compared to traditional algorithms which ignore such variability in particle composition. Importantly, this general adaptive approach can be applied to improve estimation of other biogeochemically important properties of seawater which determine ecosystem function and influence water quality and fisheries production.

To date, the project has led to six presentations at scientific venues, three of them at large international conferences, and four publications in the peer-reviewed scientific literature. Data from the project has been shared with other Arctic researchers and made publicly-available in online open access scientific data repositories. One undergraduate and two graduate students received training in scientific data analysis, optical oceanography, and Arctic ecology, and led to the completion of one MS and one PhD degree.
